claim: King Kong (2005 film) was the lead actress's biggest box office role.

supporting.text: King Kong (2005) grossed over $550 million worldwide, making it one of the highest-grossing films of Naomi Watts' career.

attacks.text: King Kong (2005) grossed over $550 million worldwide, making it one of the highest-grossing films of Naomi Watts' career.
Naomi Watts starred in The Ring (2002), which grossed $249 million worldwide on a $48 million budget, achieving higher profitability than King Kong (2005).
King Kong (2005) had a production budget of $207 million, meaning its $550 million gross represents a lower return on investment compared to smaller films in Watts' filmography.
The Ring's success was largely attributed to its cultural zeitgeist and horror genre appeal rather than Watts' star power, unlike King Kong's reliance on her lead performance.
Adjusted for inflation, some of Watts' earlier roles in critically acclaimed films like Mulholland Drive (2001) may have comparable cultural impact despite lower nominal box office.

supporting.text: Naomi Watts' other major roles, such as in Mulholland Drive or The Ring, did not achieve the same box office success as King Kong.

attacks.text: Naomi Watts' other major roles, such as in Mulholland Drive or The Ring, did not achieve the same box office success as King Kong.
The Ring (2002) grossed over $249 million worldwide, while King Kong (2005) grossed $550 million, but The Ring had a significantly lower budget, making it more profitable.
Box office success should be measured by absolute revenue, not profitability, as the claim is about the biggest box office role, not the most profitable.

Naomi Watts' role in Birdman (2014) was part of a Best Picture-winning film, which may not have matched King Kong's box office but had greater critical and awards success, redefining her career impact.
The claim specifically refers to box office success, not critical acclaim or awards, so Birdman's achievements are irrelevant to the comparison.

supporting.text: Watts starred in The Impossible (2012), which, while not as high-grossing as King Kong, earned her critical acclaim and awards recognition, potentially making it a bigger career milestone.

attacks.text: Watts starred in The Impossible (2012), which, while not as high-grossing as King Kong, earned her critical acclaim and awards recognition, potentially making it a bigger career milestone.
Box office success is a more objective and measurable indicator of an actor's biggest role than critical acclaim.
Critical acclaim and awards can significantly elevate an actor's career and public profile, sometimes more than box office numbers.
King Kong (2005) had a much larger budget and marketing campaign, which contributed to its higher box office, not necessarily Watts' performance.

supporting.text: Watts' role in Birdman (2014) was part of an ensemble cast in a Best Picture-winning film, which may hold more prestige than King Kong's box office performance.

attacks.text: Watts' role in Birdman (2014) was part of an ensemble cast in a Best Picture-winning film, which may hold more prestige than King Kong's box office performance.
Box office revenue is a measurable metric of a film's commercial success, while prestige is subjective and varies by audience.
King Kong (2005) grossed over $550 million worldwide, significantly more than Birdman's $103 million, making it a more commercially impactful role for Watts.
Prestige from awards like Best Picture can elevate an actor's career and marketability beyond what box office numbers alone achieve.

supporting.text: King Kong's budget and marketing scale far exceeded most of Watts' other films, ensuring it reached a wider audience and higher box office numbers.

attacks.text: King Kong's budget and marketing scale far exceeded most of Watts' other films, ensuring it reached a wider audience and higher box office numbers.
Naomi Watts starred in The Ring (2002), which had a higher box office return relative to its budget and a broader cultural impact.
The Ring's success was more significant for Watts' career, as it established her as a leading actress, whereas King Kong was an ensemble piece.
King Kong's box office performance was underwhelming relative to its budget, failing to break even during its theatrical run.
Despite not breaking even, King Kong still grossed more in absolute terms than any other film in Watts' career at the time.

supporting.text: Watts' recurring role in the Twin Peaks revival (2017) garnered significant cultural impact, which may outweigh King Kong's financial success in terms of career significance.

attacks.text: Watts' recurring role in the Twin Peaks revival (2017) garnered significant cultural impact, which may outweigh King Kong's financial success in terms of career significance.
King Kong (2005) grossed over $550 million worldwide, making it Naomi Watts' highest-grossing film by a wide margin.
Box office earnings are an objective measure of a film's commercial success, while cultural impact is subjective and harder to quantify.
The Twin Peaks revival had niche appeal and limited viewership compared to King Kong's mass audience reach.
Naomi Watts received widespread critical acclaim and award nominations for her performance in King Kong, not just commercial success.
